nodes.text: CEOs must recognize that large IT projects carry a disproportionately high risk of catastrophic overruns and failures driven by a fat-tail distribution of rare but extreme events
We conducted the largest global study of IT change initiatives, examining 1,471 projects and comparing budgets and estimated benefits with actual costs and results
The study found an average cost overrun of 27 percent across projects, but this average conceals extreme outliers
Fully one in six projects in the sample were 'Black Swans' with average cost overruns of about 200 percent and schedule overruns of almost 70 percent
Focusing on average overruns misses the true risk because a disproportionate number of projects incur massive overages in a fat tail
High-impact IT project failures have caused executive firings and company collapses (examples: Levi Strauss, Kmart, Auto Windscreens, EADS, Hong Kong airport losses)
IT systems are now integral to products and business processes and therefore IT projects pose a singular organizational risk
The biggest IT project failures typically occur in companies already under financial or competitive stress, where projects can compound existing problems

Common causes of massive overruns include high complexity, integration and configuration mismatches across sites and versions (examples: Airbus wiring/version mismatch, Toll Collect integration problems)

Sample characteristics: average project cost was $167 million, largest $33 billion; sample skewed toward public agencies (92%) and U.S. projects (83%) with little systematic difference to other sectors

Perform a stress test: ask if the company can absorb its largest tech project going over budget by 400 percent with only 25-50 percent of benefits realized, and whether 15 percent of medium projects could exceed estimates by 200 percent
Adopt mitigation practices: break big projects into limited-size modules, create contingencies for unavoidable risks, and use reference class forecasting to improve estimates

Case evidence: Emirates NBD successfully doubled project scope after merger and completed with only 18 percent cost overrun and 7 percent schedule slip by resisting scope changes, modularizing work, keeping teams stable, and focusing on readiness to go live

Conclusion: Because IT projects produce rare but extreme failures, top managers must give careful attention to IT risk, apply stress tests and mitigation methods, and treat major IT initiatives as strategic business endeavors
